isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics Model Years 1999-2000 - MECHANICAL DIAGNOSTICS - PERFORMANCE DIAGNOSTICS - Fuel Pressure Test

svcsubproc.title: Purpose
svcsubproc.para: To determine if fuel system has clean fuel and correct pressure to start and run the engine.

warning.para: Read all safety instructions in this manual before doing this procedure.

step1.para: Inspect fuel. Fuel must be clean, free of air, contaminants, water, icing or clouding. Fuel should be straw colored. Dyed fuel ( red or blue) indicates designation for off-highway use.
Check for gasoline or kerosene odors.

note.para: Engine oil in the fuel may indicate an injector O-ring leak and loss of injection control pressure. To determine the cause of oil in the fuel, see Low ICP Pressure Test (Test13), including ICP Leakage Test in Hard Start/No Start Diagnostics in this section.

step1.para: If gasoline or kerosene is found in tank, drain and refill tank.

warning.para: Read all safety instructions in this manual before doing this procedure.

step1.para: Remove air bleed valve on fuel filter header.
Install a 1/8 in (3 mm) pipe fitting in place of the bleed valve.
Connect a line from the fitting to Gauge Bar.
Measure fuel pressure at high idle. Record pressure on Mechanical Diagnostics form EGED-180-2 and compare to specifications.
If fuel pressure is low after replacing the fuel filter, do the following:

step2.para: Remove fuel return line and install plug (to prevent fuel from exiting) into fuel return opening.

Crank engine and check fuel pressure gauge. If fuel pressure rises, replace fuel return valve and recheck fuel pressure. If fuel pressure does not increase, do Transfer Pump Restriction Test (Test 3).

note.para: Do Fuel Pressure Test (Test 11), before removing pressure test equipment.

item.para: In-line fuel valve shut off (if equipped)
Fuel supply line from tank broken, crimped or kinked.
Incorrect fuel grade for cold temperatures. Fuel waxed or jelled (most likely grade 2 fuel). Pickup tube in tank could be clogged or cracked.
Water, ice, or contaminants in the tank and fuel system stopping fuel flow.
Plugged supplemental filters or water separators causing the fuel system to draw air.
Gauge Bar (PS94-831-3) and appropriate line with 1/8 in (3 mm) NPT fitting
